questions.question:
Question 1: A scar excision followed by reconstruction with a split skin graft was performed on the 
forearm of a 28-year-old man. The survival of the graft during the first 48 hours will be 
mainly dependent on  
.
questions.explanation:
Skin grafts survive by imbibition during the first 48 hours. The stage of imbibition is the first stage of graft uptake during which the graft draws nourishment 
from the plasma exudate at the host site (by simple diffusion). After this inosculation and 
revascularization take over.

questions.question:
Question 2: A patient with a leg injury was treated with a skin graft as shown below. Which of the 
following statements is false regarding this type of skin graft?

options.a: Degree of contraction is dependant on amount of dermis in graft
options.b: Healing with abnormal pigmentation are more common.
options.d: Meshing grafts improve their ultimate cosmetic appearance

questions.explanation:
The given image shows a meshed, split-thickness skin graft. Split grafts are meshed to expand the 
surface area that can be covered but it does not improve the cosmetic appearance. Less dermis in the split-thickness skin graft translates into less primary contraction (the degree to 
which a graft shrinks in surface area after harvesting and before grafting) and more secondary 
contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks during healing). 1117 
Sold by @itachibot Less dermis also translates into a better chance of graft survival. Thin split grafts have a low 
primary contraction, high secondary contraction, and high reliability of graft take. However, they 
tend to heal with abnormal pigmentation and poor durability. The image given below shows the procedure of obtaining a split-thickness skin graft using a 
handheld Humby knife. Type of graft 
Split-thickness graft 
Full-thickness graft Composition 
Epidermis + part of the derm

questions.question:
Question 3: A 34-year-old man sustains facial burns and is being planned for reconstruction with a skin 
graft. Which type of graft should he receive to achieve a better cosmetic appearance and 
minimal contraction?
questions.explanation:
The patient should receive a Wolfe graft to achieve a better cosmetic appearance and minimal 
contraction. Wolfe grafts are full-thickness skin grafts that are used for small areas of skin 
replacement where good elastic skin that will not contract is required (such as fingers, eyelids, and 
facial parts). Option B: Partial-thickness skin grafts or split-thickness grafts are called Thiersch grafts. They 
consist of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis. They tend to heal with abnormal 1118 
Sold by @itachibot pigmentation and result in suboptimal cosmetic appearance. Option C: Composite grafts are grafts that contain skin and fat or skin and cartilage. They are 
often taken from the ear margin and useful for rebuilding missing elements of the nose, eyelids, 
and fingertips. Option D: Blair-Brown grafts are a type of intermediate thickness split skin graft. Full-thickness skin graft (Wol 
fe) Split thickness skin graft (Thi 
ersche) Epidermis +part of dermis Structure

questions.question: Question 4: The most common cause of skin graft failure is

options.d: Poor quality of the recipient bed

questions.explanation:
The most common cause of skin graft failure is hematoma under the graft, where the blood clot is 
a barrier to contact of the graft and bed for revascularization. Other causes are shearing or movement of the graft on the bed, infection, poor quality of the 
recipient bed, and characteristics of the graft itself, such as thickness or vascularity of the donor 
site.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 20-year-old lady sustained extensive burns over her left forearm for which a split-thickness 
skin graft was planned. During surgery, after obtaining a skin graft from the anterior thigh, 
the patient became hemodynamically unstable and a transplant to the forearm could not be 
completed. What would you do with the harvested graft?

options.a: It must be discarded and fresh graft harvested before repeat surgery
options.b: It can be stored for up to 2-3 days at +4°C in saline
options.c: It can be stored for up to 2-3 weeks at +4°C in saline
options.d: It can be stored for 2-3 months at +4°C in saline

questions.explanation:
The harvested graft can be stored at +4°C in refrigeration after wrapping it in a sterile gauze pad 
moistened with saline. The process of harvesting and storing skin grafts is called skin banking. 
Skin banks store grafts using various methods. Most commonly preferred is to store the graft for 
up to 2-3 weeks at +4°C. 1119 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following is true with respect to a skin graft harvested from the post-auricular 
area?
questions.explanation:
Graft harvested from the postauricular area is a full-thickness skin graft. As it involves harvesting 
the complete dermis donor site needs to be sutured following harvest. Option A: Humby knife is used to harvest split-thickness skin grafts (Thiersche grafts). Full-thickness skin graft (Wol

questions.question:
Question 7: A child is being prepared for a Millard’s repair as seen in the image. The factors influencing 
the development of his condition are all except  
.
questions.explanation:
1120 
Sold by @itachibot Vitamin A deficiency during pregnancy is not a factor influencing the development of cleft 
lip/palate. Millard’s repair is the most common surgical repair of cleft lip and is usually performed 
between 3 to 6 months of age. The cause of orofacial clefting is felt to be multifactorial. Factors that likely increase the incidence 
of clefting include increased parental age, drug use and infections during pregnancy, and smoking 
during pregnancy.

questions.question:
Question 8: The given image shows a forearm flap harvested for the reconstruction of the oral cavity of a 
45-year-old patient with squamous cell carcinoma. Identify the type of flap. 1111 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The picture shows a radial forearm free flap. Fasciocutaneous radial forearm free flap is the most 
common free flap used in head and neck reconstruction. A flap defines the tongue of tissue whereas a pedicle is used to describe the base or stem with the 
vascular supply. In a free flap, the blood supply is isolated, disconnected, and then reconnected using microsurgery 
at the new site. Other Eg for free flaps: free fibular flap, DIEP flap (Deep inferior epigastric 
perforators) Option A: Axial flaps are much longer and are based on known blood vessels. Eg: Latissmus Dorsi 
flap, TRAM (Transverse rectus abdominis myocutaneous) flap. Option B: An islanded flap is that in which the axial blood supply is swung round on a stalk. Option D: A random flap includes three sides of a rectangle, bearing no specific relationship to 
where the blood supply enters. Eg: V-Y plasty, Z plasty, Limberg, or rhomboid flap.

questions.question: Question 9: The flap shown in the picture is which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a serratus anterior flap. The serratus anterior flap is a highly reliable flap 
with a consistently long pedicle. Its anatomy permits coverage of complex wounds. The 1121 
Sold by @itachibot underlying rib can be included as a myoosseous flap to expand the versatility of this flap. Classification of muscle flaps Axial flapNamed vessel suppl 
ying flap. Based on blood supply

questions.question:
Question 10: The image shows a surgical technique used to release Dupuytren's contracture. Which of the 
following statements is true regarding this?

options.a: It can also be used in the surgical management of keloid scars and contractures
options.b: It reorients the direction of the central wound by 90 degrees
options.c: Triangular flaps created using 60 degrees can lengthen the scar by 50%
options.d: It is a type of local advancement flap

questions.explanation:
The image shows a typical example of a Z Plasty. It is a type of transposition flap that incorporates qualities of both advancement and rotation 
flaps. Z plasty is used for the lengthening of linear scars. It is best used in releasing simple 
contractures. Usually, all the limbs are of equal length and ideally, the angle between them is 60°. Two 
triangular flaps are raised. Theoretically, a 60-degree angle flap will result in a 75% increase in the 
length of the scar and a 90-degree reorientation of central wound. Angles smaller than 60 degrees are easier to transpose but result in less lengthening and 
realignment of the scar to less than 90 degrees. Angles larger than 60 degrees should be avoided 
because the force required to transpose the flaps increases markedly, making the closure of the 
wound difficult. Relative contraindications to Z-plasty include patients with keloids and hypertrophic scarring 
tendencies. 1122 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A truck driver undergoes a Limberg flap operation using a random flap for recurrent pilonidal 
sinus infections. What is the generally accepted safe and reliable length: width ratio for this 
type of flap?
questions.explanation:
The Limberg flap is a type of random flap and the safe and reliable length:width ratio for the 
random flap 3:1. Random pattern flaps have a blood supply based on small, unnamed blood vessels in the 
dermal-subdermal plexus, as opposed to the discrete, well described, directional vessels of axial 
pattern flaps. As random flaps have a variable blood supply, they need an adequate base (width) to 
survive. The rhomboid (Limberg) flap involves creating a skin flap with two opposing angles of 60° and 
120° at the corners, forming a rhomboid shape positioned directly next to the defect. The design 
allows the flap to be rotated into the defect, with the donor site closed primarily, ensuring 
minimal distortion to the surrounding tissues. This method is especially useful in areas like the 
gluteal region, where complex closure techniques help achieve optimal results.

questions.question:
Question 12: A free flap is used to resurface a tendoachilles defect in a 58-year-old chronic smoker. As a 
first-year surgical resident, you are asked to monitor the flap for venous occlusion. Which of 
the following should you be looking out for?
questions.explanation:
The first sign of venous occlusion in a free flap is increasing warmth. Clinical signs of arterial and venous compromise in a free flap: Note: Venous and arterial compromise may coexist, and one may lead to the other. Clinical Sign

h Quickening (and darkening)

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is true about the flap given in the image.

options.a: Pedicled TRAM based on superior epigastric artery
options.b: Free TRAM based on superior and inferior epigastric artery
options.c: DIEP based on deep inferior epigastric artery
options.d: Lower Abdominal Fat based inferior epigastric vessels

questions.explanation:
The given image showing only skin and fat moved to the chest is suggestive of a deep inferior 
epigastric artery perforator flap (DIEP), based on the deep inferior epigastric artery. DIEP is a variant of TRAM flap and free flap where only the skin and fat are moved to the chest. 
A microvascular technique is used in which no muscle is taken and the perforating vessels are 
dissected out. 1123 
Sold by @itachibot As the muscle is spared in DIEP, there is a reduced risk of abdominal wall weakness and its 
associated complications. Other options: Options A and B: The pedicled TRAM flap is based on the superior epigastric artery and the free 
TRAM flap is based on superior and inferior epigastric arteries (supercharged TRAM flap); 
however, the given image depicts a deep inferior epigastric artery flap. In TRAM flaps: • The skin, fat, and muscle are moved to the chest. • It provides good cosmesis and bulk since it has a soft tissue consistency similar to the breast. • Disadvantages include epigastric bulge, partial flap loss, fat necrosis, abdominal wall weakness, 
and hernias. The given image below shows a TRAM flap:

questions.question:
Question 14: A 30-year-old woman who underwent a skin-sparing mastectomy a year ago has returned to 
your clinic to discuss her options for breast reconstruction. All of the following are options to 
consider except: 1114 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: A TRAM flap provides the best cosmetic result than LD flap
options.b: An LD flap provides adequate bulk of breast tissue
options.c: Reconstruction may be delayed or immediate
options.d: Capsular contraction is a dreaded complication of silicone implants

questions.explanation:
An LD flap does not provide the bulk required and is usually used along with an implant. It is 
based on the thoracodorsal pedicle. It is an axial flap. 1124 
Sold by @itachibot Transverse rectus abdominus myocutaneous (TRAM) flap is either based on superior epigastric or 
inferior epigastric or both (supercharged TRAM). Skin, fat, and muscle are moved to the chest. It 
provides good cosmesis and bulk. An implant is usually not required.Since the rectus abdominis 
muscle is excised in the procedure, it can lead to abdominal wall weakness and hernias. The timing of reconstruction may be immediate or delayed. Impediments to immediate 
reconstruction include insufficient theatre time and a lack of experienced reconstructive surgeons. 
In addition, the patient is likely to need post-op radiotherapy, then a delayed reconstruction using 
a flap often gives better results. The easiest type of reconstruction is using a silicone gel implant under the pectoralis major 
muscle. Capsular contraction is a dreaded complication of silicone implants.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 35-year-old man with osteosarcoma of the mandibular ramus is planned for resection and 
reconstruction with a flap. The flap used most commonly in mandibular reconstruction is 
based on which of the following vascular structures?
questions.explanation:
1125 
Sold by @itachibot The most commonly used osseous flap for mandibular reconstruction is the fibular free flap. The 
fibular free flap is based on the peroneal artery and vein, and the blood supply to the foot should 
be investigated before harvesting this flap. Common flaps and their uses The free fibular flap may also be used to correct the Andy Gump deformity. It is an anterior 
mandibular defect that creates the appearance of an absent chin and lower lip and severely 
retrognathic lower jaw, which is named after a character in an early 20th-century comic strip. Name of flap

questions.question:
Question 16: A 56-year-old patient suffering from alcoholic cirrhosis receives a healthy liver from his 
biological son. What is this type of transplant known as?
questions.explanation:
Transplant of an organ/tissue from a son to a parent is an example of an allograft. An allograft is transplant of cells/tissues/organs from a genetically non-identical donor of the same 
species. Isografts are allografts in which cells/tissues/organs are transplanted from a donor to a genetically 
identical recipient. (monozygotic twins)

questions.question:
Question 17: What incision would you make to excise a lesion on the bridge of the nose, in order to cause 
minimal scarring?
questions.explanation:
A horizontal incision should be taken as the relaxed skin tension lines (Borge's lines) at the bridge 
of the nose are horizontal. Aligning a surgical incision or excision with skin tension lines results in minimal tension across 
the closure of the defect. This leads to optimal scar formation and minimizes wound contraction. Skin tension lines reflect internal tension within the skin and are produced by the parallel 
alignment of connective tissue of the dermis. Several different skin tension lines have been 
described. Borge's lines which are also called relaxed skin tension lines are most useful to guide 
surgical incision. These are often confused with Langer's lines. Langer's lines, also called cleavage lines are topological lines drawn based on the shape of wounds 
on cadavers. These were not intended as a guide for surgical incisions and they do not always 
correspond to the best orientation of skin tension and often run perpendicular to skin folds. On 
the face, these two sets of lines often run at right angles to one another.

questions.question:
Question 18: 1115 
Sold by @itachibot A plastic surgeon performs an upper eyelid reconstruction using a tarsoconjunctival flap for a 
patient who underwent a sebaceous gland carcinoma excision. What is the maximum tissue 
loss for which a primary repair would have sufficed?
questions.explanation:
1127 
Sold by @itachibot Defects comprising <25% of the upper eyelid can generally be closed primarily in pentagonal 
approximating fashion. For defects involving 25–50% of the upper eyelid, lateral canthotomy and cantholysis can be 
performed. Defects more than 50% need proper flap cover.

questions.question:
Question 19: A mother brings her 3-week-old baby to the pediatrics OPD, with a lesion on his abdomen 
which has been growing in size since birth. On examination, the lesion is red, nodular, and 
blanches on pressure. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of infantile hemangioma. Only monitoring of the lesion is 
required as in 50% of cases, complete involution is seen by 5 years of age. Hemangioma growth frequently peaks before the first year, and then the lesions enter the 
involuting phase. The involution phase begins in 50% of children by 5 years of age and in 70% by 
7 years of age. It continues until 10 years of age. Indications for immediate treatment are complications such as ulceration or those pertaining to 
the location of the mass (e.g. visual issues due to large hemangioma over eyelid). Treatment options include: • Beta blockers - oral propranolol • Steroids - intralesional triamcinolone, topical clobetasol, systemic steroids • Interferon alfa-2a and vincristine - for steroid-resistant lesions • Local resection with cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser 1128 
Sold by @itachibot Thorax & Lungs
